ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a in-depth knowledge of the poetry and correspondence of Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Lowell.

Coming into ENGL 345, I was somewhat acquainted with the poetry of Elizabeth Bishop but knew little about the poetry of Robert Lowell or of the longstanding rapport between the two poets. Getting to dive deeply into both poets' bibliographies chronologically, alongside their decades of correspondences, was a deeply rewarding literary and cultural study.

I became familiar with Bishop's and Lowell's catalogues, reading their poetry across multiple collections and perusing their correspondence. I also had the opportunity to practice my poetry analysis skills, via both classroom discussion and paper writing.
I learned about the literary friendship between Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Lowell and about their respective writing styles and work.
This course really helped me learn how to better analyze poetry, discover nuances I would have otherwise missed, and make connections between the poetry of both writers and their personal letters.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The poetry is great (Bishop is definitely a poet's poet) and the structure is perfect for a senior seminar. The readings are very reasonable, which allow you to spend more time on the poems before coming to class. And Professor Hammer is extremely kind and knowledgeable about the subject. 

Weaknesses: None.

I thought ENGL 345 was a very strong course. Unfortunately, the nature of reading one or more books of poetry each week means that there simply isn't time to discuss everything in detail, but I don't think this can be helped -- and it was still wonderful to engage with the work on my own time.
Prof. Hammer has strong familiarity/ knowledge of course material, and the seminar format makes for productive conversations around the readings.

I loved that this was a discussion-based course. Professor Hammer did a great job of structuring the discussion and offering insights while allowing the majority of class time to be dedicated to students sharing their ideas. I cannot think of any areas of improvement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in Bishop and/or Lowell. They are both fantastic poets in their own right (especially Bishop), and it was fascinating to read their letters to each other as well. Professor Hammer is also awesome.
I would definitely recommend ENGL 345 to anyone interested in 20th century poetry or in the social spheres of contemporary English-language literature.

I would recommend this course primarily to students who are already enthusiastic about Bishop and Lowell. Read some of their poems before applying; although there's definitely variation within their catalogues, each writer does have a very particular style that can become difficult to work with if you realize it's not your thing. If you like what you see, absolutely dive inthe discussions are fascinating and Professor Hammer is amazing.
Yes! I enjoyed this course so much!
Yes, even if they are not familiar with Bishop and Lowell. Anyone interested in English or writing in general would benefit from the readings and discussions in this course.
